comments.commentBody: I thought so, but then I wondered about Citation, so I decided to ask rather than assume.  Thanks!
Kevin Brock meant to say 100 MW, not 100 mW.  Mega not milli.

To answer your question, Henry, no. We have not learned not to get involved in another country's internal problems by now. We will never learn.

We will never learn because there are people here whose hearts bleed for "the innocent" so badly that they are willing to always risk *other* Americans' lives and our money so that they can feel better about themselves. And there are those who see in these situations an opportunity for American hegemony that can be secured at the end of the barrel of a gun.

When people take it upon themselves to overthrow their government they - and we - should expect that many will be killed. Revolution is a nasty proposition, but its consequences should be accepted when initiated.

There is no amount of intervention that can adequately soothe those concerned with suffering. People suffer and they will continue to suffer, and there is little to nothing we can do without again risking our fellow citizens' lives and more of our financial well-being for others' cause. The Syrians initially chose their course so they must now live with its consequences.

AS for the others getting involved such as Iran and Hezbollah, the UN should have made it clear from the beginning that no intervention on either combatant's part would be tolerated.

Allowing others to get involved causes proxy wars, in which the original combatants become pawns for others' interests. Let the Syrians have their revolution but make everyone else stay out of it.

You ask, "Haven't we learned not to get involved in a country's civil war by now?"

Apparently not, Henry.

The Saudi and Qatar are happy to give McCain the money as they did for the invasion of Kuwait by Allied forces.
They will also be very happy to send a few more planeloads of their country man for another 9-11after all they consider the USA a Satan.
What is a few American lives for the greater good of "America" with Saudi money.

Haven't we learned not to get involved in a country's civil war by now?  How many times do we have to be defeated, how many more Americans are going to have to die and how much money do we have to spend to see that there is nothing in this war for our people and our country?  McCain and the rest of these Republican war mongers have never seen a war they didn't like.  To hell with spending our money on insuring Americans, but they are all for spending money on more war.  Iran is the real target.  If Iraq was hard, Iran will be harder:  a large country with over 80 million people.  Of course, McCain will tell us the Iranians will welcome us in.  Oh yeah, just like the Iraqis did Senator.  Let the Syrians fight it out.  Let the Saudis send in their men to fight a proxy war with Iran.  If the French want to get involved, cheers and good luck.  But keep us out of this one and until we pay for our last two wars, don't get us involved in another one.

As I understand it, much of the conflict (and not only in Syria) is based on the Sunnis' belief that the Shia are trying to wipe them out. With the triumph of Shias over Sunnis in Iraq who could blame them for thinking that was US policy?
Because you see wars support the military industrial complex -- and the bankers who finance wars. They run the show.
@Rob DL: one can deliver humanitarian aid without intervening.
That would have complicated the narrative. God forbid there be moral greyness in American foreign policy!

Only 13 centuries of sectarian violence? Gee, that sounds really likely.

Maybe, the "O" man can take his olive branch and draw a line in the sand!
Thank you for your comment.  It is appreciated.
To be fair, Charles, NYT publishes  both sides of the argument on this particular issue so far.

There is no way knowing what I know about this situation that I can just sit back and remain silent while once again US military lives are thrown away for the benefit of the profits of Saudi Aramco. For over 40 years now the US military has been the unofficial 9-11 service for the royal cut throats of Arabia that don't give a rats @$$ for the lives of the thousands of US solders who lives have been lost to keep these royal cut throats in power and priviledge. This is an abomination that is beyond all reconning and made possible owing to the trillions of $$$ controlled by the Al-Sauds.

Why is there no mention of the oil pipeline built by the Russians through Syria and the terminal built by the Russians at Tartous for the off loading of crude onto tankers there? Because once again people would see that this phoney war is once again all about oil and the fact that the interests of Lukoil cut across those of Aramco.

Once again the NY Times as well as all the other manipulators of public opinion find that the facts are inconvenient and the public just doesn't need to know about such things that are the real determiners of war.

I have not forgotten the perfidious role of star NY Times correspondent Judith Miller in the selling of the war of aggression against Iraq which was proven to have been based solely on lies and misconstruction of whatever facts did exist.

By refusing to do its job properly US media has made itself complicit in these ongoing war crimes.

Where have you been the last 25 years? It's that easy eh? "Problem solved"? Dangerously simplistic thinking.

American drones are not the answer to every tragic situation in the world. Neither is force.
Remember sir,England won the battle,but lost the war.Aint it all Medieval age nonsense anyway,here in the 21st century?{Which is starting to go dark ages).

"Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more;"
Shakespeare - Henry V

When you think about it, all wars are as they are often fought by individuals who really don't have a say in the matter.  Rarely do those who actually want the war/initiate the war actually go into the battle.  Probably never these days.

Contrary to the old proverb "Speak softly and carry a big stick",  we tend to speak loudly and furnish others with big sticks,  only to go in later ourselves with more and bigger sticks.  We never seem to learn.....
America arms the rebels and Russia arms Assad. It's a proxy war.
Christians?  You really believe the administration cares one bit about Christians?
I think you mean "bite the hand that BOMBS them."

Aming the Syrian rebels even with small arms and amunition is the came's nose under the tent. We do not even know who these rebels are - they don't themselves who they are - they costantly bicker. The only force with any strength to oppose Assad is the Al Nusra, front AKA AL Quaeda -- is that who we are planning to arm?

You do realize that if 90,000 have been killed now -- and we get involved the number of killed will go higher. If Assad loses Obama will have the blood of Christian, Druze, Alawites on his hand -as Al Quaeda gets in and alsughter anyone who does not support it. Do we really want to get into that mess. If that happens - what next drone strikes?

Remember we are not talking Halabja here - we are talking about 100 to 150 people and they could have Al quaeda. This was a pretty small scale attack and could have been accidentaly with these few death. Hardly something for us to spend billions of dollars we don't have on supporting people whom we don't know and who hate us.

Believe when this is over - we will have one more enemy in the Middle East who hates and wants to destroy us no matter who wins.

The US can only lose in this situation so we should stay out of it. Stay with Humanitrian aid - it is not up to the US to put i[ billions of dollars just to oust Assad. We need that money here at home - stop spending moeny on people who will only bite the hand that feeds them and spit in our face.

Reasons, not excuses. Al Qaeda is one. Muslim Brotherhood is two. Weapons will be used again US and Israel  are three and four. Syrian refuges some will be terrorists allowed to immigrate as refugees by Obama. is number five.  Shall I go on?

Do you mean the rebels killing the Alawites and Christians?
Detonate car bombs in the streets to kill passing pedestrians children woman and all
We should give them more weapons to completely eliminate all Christians now left in Syria that lived there for hundreds if not thousand years.
Yes some people need to get their heads screwed on and spend time to read more history not propaganda

So you are fine with ending SS and Medicare in order to get involved in another pointless middle east venture? Because that's what will happen. You are saying that the Syrians are more important to you than your fellow citizens.

I personally find the excuses used here to justify not helping innocent Syrians murdered and under assault by the horror of chemicals weapons and the genocidal Assad ("not in our interests," etc. etc.) to be completely disgusting from a humanitarian perspective.

If you're interests are so narrow minded ("can't someone else do it?") so as to allow the wholesale murder in the tens of thousands of people, you need to get your head screwed on right.

Read the White House statement  (link below this headline), this article reads way too much into what's actually been said. I'm afraid NYT is engaged in wishful thinking at best, or shamefully conspiring to force Obama's hand.
Patricia - Obama boxes himself in quite often by what he says.

Hezbollah will "make trouble" for Israel??!?

You mean by not allowing Israel to invade Lebanon and murder its citizens?

America needs to stop making the same interventionist mistake over and over again. Every country or group involved in the Syrian civil war is loser. It is death a struggle between Moslem religious sects fighting under black flags. Let them find an answer to their mutual annihilation. We have too many problems of our own to worry about theirs. No doubt Iran and Hezbollah will try to make trouble for Israel, but consider they will be in a better position to have the confrontation they want if the US is in Syria. Our participation will only be another jihadi call to arms - not that we shouldn't smite as many jihadis as we can, but let's do it on our terms. And why help a movement when its core player is Al Qaeda?

This is not a battle for freedom or truth or human dignity. This is a vicious war of mutual annihilation and the participants will turn on us with all the murderous hatred they have for each other. We gain nothing and lose much. We once followed George Washington's good advice. This is not our war. Let us not spill our blood and squander our treasure. We meddled in Soviet Afghanistan and got Osama bin Laden and al Qaeda. We went to Afghanistan again and ended up building a Pashtun Narco-terro empire. We toppled Saddam Hussein and brought al Qaeda and bloody chaos to a previously stable Iraq - for what, to give the Chinese a steady supply of oil?

What a bitter disappointment this president has become. Neocons and Neoliberals. Fakes and hypocrites all.

Mr. Appledorf, please. Shouldn't your post read "Can't we all just get along?" With all respect to what I suspect is a very honorable and caring perspective on your part, I suggest you go back to the Neville Chamberlain biography you were reading. It is Assad that is blowing up and gassing his own people to death, and likely very many Syrian children without any security of their own. Sometimes the best way to stop a bully is to stand up to him, which is what I teach the bullied children I counsel.
Let's leave Assad where he is.  His replacements are more blood thirsty.  Remember the videos?

These are Saddam Hussein's WMDs finally getting used. His scientists may be congratulating each other now that they see their ''products'' work. You were not supposed to have figured this out, so NO ONE has said anything about how Syria never had an industry set up to make these gas weapons. But that's okay, go ahead and -

Blame George Bush.
This smacks of our arming of Iraq and Iran against each other in the 1980s. Neither side's victory represented any gain for us. Let's sit this one out before our "small arms" are used against us

I totally disagree. America is the world's only superpower. With that comes responsibility. Our country is not isolated. Quite the opposite. Have you ever been to an airport? Do you recall 9/11? Need I say more? Aside from that our economy relies on global stability. Obama is doing the right thing. Keep in mind that we do not live in a perfect world.

Join right up Kacee.  And while you're at it, pony up an income tax surcharge to pay for it.  Maybe you're ready to do the former, but I sure hope you have to do at least the latter if push comes to shove and we're in the middle.  Churchill and FDR were dealing with a direct and demonstrated threat against US, especially Churchill.  But please keep in mind that a common British attitude was they they'd "fight until the last American."  So, again, join  up, re-up or otherwise grab your gun and your money and go for it.   I won't be grabbing any gun, but likely my money will get grabbed.  You should offer to pay my share.

It's a shame that so many educators bought into the idea of the strictly monetary value of a university education and, with that, the sharp class division between those who have it and those who do not.  There ought to be more emphasis on the importance of education  in itself -- from elementary school on -- for informed citizenship in a democracy.  And, there ought to be more recognition that wages should reflect not only the level of formal training for a job, but the importance of that job to our communities.  Many important and essential jobs do not truly require university or community college education, though they require a host of skills of different types.  Ironically, many of these "basic" jobs in the fabric of a community -- the delivery person, the bus driver, the trash collector -- are ones that are not easily outsourced or replaced wholly by technology.  The tight link between a college education and employment demeans the value of essential jobs and ultimately devalues a college education itself.  After all, if we promise that a college education is a ticket to a higher-paying job, and it proves not to be so, what rationale are we left with?

Thank you, Janice, for these meaningful and profound insights. I'm not a hospice nurse, but I have seen what you describe here. Love cannot be "purchased" like new car, a fancy bit of electronic technology or a large house. People so often mix up materialism with genuine love and caring; they think that material things demonstrate their love (or good taste, or moral superiority) and I assure you that, in the end, we are all the same. Death is indeed "the great equalizer"; or to quote Jim Morrison, "nobody gets out of here alive".
Very well said! The greatest wealth in my life is the people around me. All else is just coins and trinkets.

There's a bit of doggeral verse called, I think, Six Feet of Earth that makes the same point. Found in a number of poetry collections, it repeats the refrain, "six feet of earth makes us all of one size."

As a hospice nurse, I have taken care of the rich and the poor and the many in between. I have taken care of people in well appointed homes, in the homes of hoarders, in homes where people live in squalor. I could tell you story after story of a dying father lying in a bed in the back room of a trailer with a ratty blanket to cover him and sobbing sons at the bedside. The love was palpable. Some might call the father a failure, but not to his loved ones. He was their hero. And I could tell you of another father dying in a beautiful home who had the finest linens and many toys but who was only attended to by paid aides hired by sons who never came home. The loneliness was painful for even a stranger to witness. I hardly call that success.

I must tell you that death is the great equalizer. And in the end, people do not want to be remembered for all the things they have aquired. They mainly want to have their friends nearby. And their loved ones. The saddest lives, and therefore deaths, are those full of regret. It matters not what you have acheived or if you are rich or poor if you are loved and have lived a life you can look back on with pride. I think that is what the bible tries to tell us, whether you are religious or not.

Based on the results of increased technology dissemination over the past thirty years, I think this argument plays right into the hands of those who moralize that poverty is the result of personal failure, i.e., laziness.  There's still much to do to bring everyone onto the same page, technologically speaking, but that alone isn't going to address the fundamental failing that Prof. Krugman discussed.  Even the best technology isn't going to create 100 million entrepreneurs, which is the tantalizing (and delusional) vision the poverty-is-a-moral-failing advocates hold out to us.

Here's how: the other piece of the puzzle, is that transformative technology is now more widely distributed and available. So, we need more ground-up technology that helps individuals. Let's develop technologies that help individual citizens on the playing field created by the corporate technologies that harm individual workers.

Reading down the center vertical, it's as if someone was hurt by a German car, and they complained about it:

AUDI ... PAIN(E) ... WhINE

I've just scrolled through about half of the comments, and haven't seen one positive word about Weiner. If no one in this semi-random sampling from the Times' readership has anything positive to say about him, his campaign is utterly doomed. (Of course, he lost my vote long ago with his anti-biking rhetoric; the recent semi-turnaround just shows him to be a crass opportunist.)

I'm also wondering if Weiner already knows that he's a goner and if this effort is solely about fast-forwarding his rehabilitation.
